author: Keiran Southern
title: North East devolution: What happens next after Government deadline is missed?

locations.name: sunderland civic centre  the north east

text:
The Government had given North East authorities a strict deadline - sign up or the deal is off - and that has now passed Shares Comments Get daily news by email L-R Terry Collins, Cllr Martin Gannon and Mike Barker during a North East Combined Authority meeting at Sunderland Civic Centre 
The North East devolution deal has been thrown into doubt after council leaders voted against moving with the plans. 
The Government had set a deadline for the deal to be pushed through - a deadline that has now passed. 
It means the future of devolution in the region is up in the air. 
So here is what we know. What happened today? 
The leaders of the North East Combined Authority , made up of the region’s seven councils, held a vote on moving the devolution deal forward to the public consultation stage. They were split 4-3, with Newcastle, Northumberland and North Tyneside voting in favour while Sunderland, Durham, South Tyneside, Gateshead voted against. 
They had already signed off on the devolution deal, this was just the next stage. What happens next? 
That’s the multi million - or should that be £3.4bn - pound question. The Government has been notified of the decision, and now the ball is in their court. Its initial reaction was not particularly illuminating. 
A Department for Communities and Local Government spokesman said: “It is disappointing that some North East councils have been unwilling to support this deal, which would certainly have benefitted local people. 
“If councils in the region wish to discuss devolution proposals further, our door remains open.” What is at stake? Billions of pounds for the region. The money is a mix of new funds as well as greater control over existing cash. 
Elsewhere in the country in the likes of Manchester, Liverpool and Sheffield, the devolution process is going a lot smoother than in the North East, and it is expected their regional mayors will be in place in 2017. Why did some leaders say no? 
The leaders of the region’s local authorities have consistently failed to come to an agreement over the multi-billion pound deal - with some accepting it in its current form and others wanting more assurances from the Government on post-Brexit funding. The region benefited greatly from European funding which it is soon to lose. And the non-negotiable requirement of an elected Mayor was a major bone of contention too. Could the North East get a mayor in 2017? 
It’s possible, but highly unlikely. That would mean the Government rushing through the process and offering another deal to satisfy the authorities who voted no on Tuesday. Could we see a North/South split between the authorities who voted yes and the ones who voted no? 
Yes. 
As it stands, the law states two combined authorities cannot overlap, and devolution depends on having a mayoral combined authority. 
But it is possible we could see a split between consenting authorities and non-consenting authorities. 
This would not happen overnight and if it was to come about would take many years.
